revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-11 09:08:04.000000000', 'message': 'fix race in test_interface_detach_with_port_with_bandwidth_request

During port detach the unbind towards neutron happens before the
port allocation is removed from placement. The functional test only
waited for the port unbind before asserted the remaining allocations and
therefore it was racy.

Fortunately the instance.interface_detach.end is emitted after the both
the unbind and the allocation shrink. So the test is changed to wait for
this notification instead.

Change-Id: I53d76d6353ae634e387672e14943f518955b221e
Closes-Bug: #1819374
'}, {'created': '2019-03-11 14:38:56.000000000', 'message': 'fix race in test_interface_detach_with_port_with_bandwidth_request

During port detach the unbind towards neutron happens before the
port allocation is removed from placement. The functional test only
waited for the port unbind before asserted the remaining allocations and
therefore it was racy.

Fortunately the instance.interface_detach.end is emitted after the both
the unbind and the allocation shrink. So the test is changed to wait for
this notification instead.

Change-Id: I53d76d6353ae634e387672e14943f518955b221e
Closes-Bug: #1819374
'}]
commit_message:
fix race in test_interface_detach_with_port_with_bandwidth_request

During port detach the unbind towards neutron happens before the
port allocation is removed from placement. The functional test only
waited for the port unbind before asserted the remaining allocations and
therefore it was racy.

Fortunately the instance.interface_detach.end is emitted after the both
the unbind and the allocation shrink. So the test is changed to wait for
this notification instead.

Change-Id: I53d76d6353ae634e387672e14943f518955b221e
Closes-Bug: #1819374

commit_message:
Disable wheel mirror updates for afs server upgrades

We are upgrading the afs fileservers. Disable the wheel mirror jobs
during this time so that they don't interfere with the upgrades.

Change-Id: I6d051d076c736f9b34ff8d905d7ced04c7645568

subject: WIP: Make fake_libvirt_utils DIAF
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 9008, 'name': 'VMware NSX CI', 'username': 'vmwareminesweeper', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 14595, 'name': 'z Systems KVM', 'email': 'zkvm-ci@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'ibm-zkvm-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23498, 'name': 'IBM zVM CI', 'email': 'zvmosci@us.ibm.com', 'username': 'zvmosci'}, {'_account_id': 26515, 'name': 'Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI', 'email': 'nova_hyperv_ci@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'nova_hyperv_ci'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-06 21:50:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-03-07 00:36:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-28837 : SUCCESS in 1h 15m 22s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-03-07 04:52:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/641489/1 : SUCCESS in 2h 21m 04s'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2019-03-11 07:10:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I really dislike this approach to be honest. I don't think we should replace old magic with new magic. Let's just remove the users in a slow boring methodical way which no one really appreciates but makes my commit stats look really good."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-11 13:36:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Fair enough mikal. This was definitely just a step in that direction, the advantage of this new magic simply being that we've gotten rid of the straight passthroughs and no longer have to mirror every new util with one. If we go brute force from the start, that'll have to wait until the very end (whenever we're able to get rid of the module entirely). Which is probably fine.

I'll abandon this once I've started on that approach.

Unless by "my commit stats" you were implying that you're going to do it :P'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-11 20:17:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So I looked into this a little further, and there's actually another advantage to doing this "new magic" first, before tracking down all the individual uses of the utils. It goes like this:

If we leave the monkey patch of libvirt_utils in place, the tests which need to mock its methods actually need to mock them on fake_libvirt_utils. This means we will need another big sweep at the end when we remove fake_libvirt_utils to switch all those mocks over to mocking from libvirt_utils itself. We also have to leave the symbols in fake_libvirt_utils in some form (e.g. have them raise an exception) because otherwise mock can't find the thing it needs to mock.

Whereas if we do this patch first, we can do the piecemeal mocks in their final form right away, and this new magic garbage will dwindle one method at a time until gone.

I'll upload a couple of patches that get rid of create_image - one on top of this one and one independently - to demonstrate the difference.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-11 20:50:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

okay, I did one of those things here [1], but then I saw how you were doing it [2], and I'm on board with that.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/642445
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:fake-libvirt-mildly-disappoints-me+(status:open+OR+status:merged)"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-11 20:50:21.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

in favor of https://review.openstack.org/#/q/topic:fake-libvirt-mildly-disappoints-me+(status:open+OR+status:merged)'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-11 16:30:21.000000000', 'message': "[CI] Bump timeout for manilaclient-dsvm-neutron-functional

On slow nodes, it may take longer than 60 minutes to have
an operational environment for us to run the tests upon.
In such environments, the tests can't be run within 20 mins.

So, bump the timeout by 10 mins.

Change-Id: Ie9b0ee92e6e18b048697f0e17273c87f3ca5cd32
"}]
commit_message:
[CI] Bump timeout for manilaclient-dsvm-neutron-functional

On slow nodes, it may take longer than 60 minutes to have
an operational environment for us to run the tests upon.
In such environments, the tests can't be run within 20 mins.

So, bump the timeout by 10 mins.

Change-Id: Ie9b0ee92e6e18b048697f0e17273c87f3ca5cd32

commit_message:
Remove keepalived purge when dvr enabled

Stop the charm from uninstalling keepalived when
using dvr since it also removes neutron-l3-agent.

Closes-Bug: #1819499

commit_message:
Add kek_rewrap functionality to Barbican

Add the ability to rewrap keks when the master key is updated
by simply doing an update.  Also, provide some needed ordering
in the steps involving MKEK and HMAC creation, sync and update.

Change-Id: I5e5a099173e82c04f4e0157049df08c8c7c47045

check that kvm kernel modules are inserted

The kvm flags in the kernel can be available
but turned off in the bios.  Check that the
kernel module for kvm is available.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-10 04:49:51.000000000', 'message': "image_uploader: raise an error when podman pull fails

It's not obvious when a podman pull fails multiple times in a row, it
was displayed as INFO, and now it will be shown at ERROR debug level for
more visibility when something is wrong with the image.

Change-Id: Ia616ae22ebf6f4c562ef7dc95ed62ada511951b4
"}]
commit_message:
image_uploader: raise an error when podman pull fails

It's not obvious when a podman pull fails multiple times in a row, it
was displayed as INFO, and now it will be shown at ERROR debug level for
more visibility when something is wrong with the image.

Change-Id: Ia616ae22ebf6f4c562ef7dc95ed62ada511951b4

commit_message:
Introduce cinder_scheduler_default_filters

Operators may want to define specific default filters. Previously,
they could only do so via cinder_cinder_conf_overrides.

Make the cinder.conf template understand cinder_scheduler_default_filters,
a list variable that, if defined, is folded into a comma-separated
list for scheduler_default_filters in the [DEFAULT] section.

Change-Id: I12859167d19b9f40e3378ac08fed094a42f40bc7

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-23 01:35:03.000000000', 'message': "Fix performance of housekeeping's DB clean up

The Housekeeping service grows in utilization of CPU as more amphorae
are created and/or marked as DELETED. The problem lays on the SELECT
statement constructed in get_all_deleted_expiring_amphora via the ORM --
it is joined eager loading all relationships.

The task does not need such amount of information, only the amphora ID.
The statement could be simplified by not loading any relationship or, at
most, lazy loading them.

This patch also fixes performance of cleaning up deleted and expired
load balancers. The code was doing multiple round-trips to the database
unecessarily:

1. retrieving all deleted LBs
2. for each LB, retrieving it again from DB to check expired date
3. delete LB

Step 1 and 2 are now condensed in get_all_deleted_expiring(), making it
a single round-trip.

Story: 2004665
Task: 28643

Change-Id: Iffc960c7c3a986328cfded1b4e408931ab0a7877

commit_message:
Fix performance of housekeeping DB clean up

The Housekeeping service grows in utilization of CPU as more amphorae
are created and/or marked as DELETED. The problem lays on the SELECT
statement constructed in get_all_deleted_expiring_amphora via the ORM --
it is joined eager loading all relationships.

The task does not need such amount of information, only the amphora ID.
The statement could be simplified by not loading any relationship or, at
most, lazy loading them.

This patch also fixes performance of cleaning up deleted and expired
load balancers. The code was doing multiple round-trips to the database
unecessarily:

1. retrieving all deleted LBs
2. for each LB, retrieving it again from DB to check expired date
3. delete LB

Step 1 and 2 are now condensed in get_all_deleted_expiring(), making it
a single round-trip.

Story: 2004665
Task: 28643

Change-Id: Iffc960c7c3a986328cfded1b4e408931ab0a7877

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-07 22:54:27.000000000', 'message': 'Improve handling of layer transfer errors

To improve the reliability of registry->registry layer transfers the
following changes have been made:
- raise an IOError to trigger a retry when the calculated digest does
  not match the expected digest
- any error when writing the blob file will remove the file

This change also ensures the tripleo-container-image-prepare writes
any exception to the log file, it appears that errors are not being
logged and the ansible task does not print its output.

Change-Id: I98f25932a66bb7a9f04cdc1c906223e457fe44b1
Closes-Bug: #1815576
'}]
commit_message:
Improve handling of layer transfer errors

To improve the reliability of registry->registry layer transfers the
following changes have been made:
- raise an IOError to trigger a retry when the calculated digest does
  not match the expected digest
- any error when writing the blob file will remove the file

This change also ensures the tripleo-container-image-prepare writes
any exception to the log file, it appears that errors are not being
logged and the ansible task does not print its output.

Change-Id: I98f25932a66bb7a9f04cdc1c906223e457fe44b1
Closes-Bug: #1815576

commit_message:
Include container build error log for logstash indexing

build-containers log is not indexed by logstash which makes
impossible to investigate errors related to them.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/639089

Change-Id: I566f55cf96335a484e2f5ca72580006d0eb47283
Closes-Bug: #1817309

commit_message:
Enable vault tls-certificates for SAML Mellon

The charm assumed the use of ssl_cert and ssl_key. The current best
practice is to deploy with vault and the tls-certificates relation.
Enable tls-certificates relation aware configuration for the
fid-service-provider relation.

Change-Id: I5441359b1d60b07c6b47ca58b45a09c4b7ac886b

commit_message:
Enable vault tls-certificates for SAML Mellon

The charm assumed the use of ssl_cert and ssl_key. The current best
practice is to deploy with vault and the tls-certificates relation.
Enable tls-certificates relation aware configuration for the
websso-trusted-dashboard relation.

Simplify hostname, IP, VIP selection using resolve_address.

Change-Id: Ibcd963946a3956f9b2d2963fe9455d6d9ee78ab6

subject: allow operator to control display of floating ip pools
messages:
[{'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-07 21:13:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-12-08 16:37:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

"is_default" of (external) network is referred only in auto-allocated-topology feature. This attribute does not affect floating IP allocation. Thus, this motivation does not make sense to me.

If you would like to discuss this more, please file a bug before submitting a patch.'}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-08 18:43:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your opinion. I wasn't aware that the is_default attribute was specifically for that use case."}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-08 19:06:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-10 00:40:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-10 00:50:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-12-12 13:32:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Could you explain why individual settings are required one by one?

The following is my first impression.
You seem to invent another thing which the neutron RBAC feature achieves.

FLOATING_IP_INCLUDE_TAGS:

If this setting is configured, floating IP pools which are not listed
in this setting are not displayed. What is a use case where it is required?
If an operator would like to expose a specific set of floating IP pools (i.e., external networks)
they should set router:external True only to such pools. For other floating IP pools if any,
they should use neutron RBAC feature [1].
I cannot imagine a use case where this is required and Neutron RBAC does not cover.
Thus, -1 to FLOATING_IP_INCLUDE_TAGS.

FLOATING_IP_EXCLUDE_TAGS:

My comment is similar to for FLOATING_IP_INCLUDE_TAGS.
I cannot imagine a use case where this is required and Neutron RBAC does not cover.
If operators would like to hide a specific set of external networks,
they should use neutron RBAC feature [1] rather than setting router:external to True.
Thus, -1 to FLOATING_IP_EXCLUDE_TAGS.

FLOATING_IP_ORDER_TAGS:
Use cases sounds reasonable.
Perhaps the setting name is not ideal. PREFERRED_FLOATING_POOLS?
At least this setting is about floating IP pools but the setting name does not include "pool". It is confusing.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-rbac.html#allowing-a-network-to-be-used-as-an-external-network'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-12-12 13:33:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-13 20:45:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-13 20:46:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Akihiro: I've moved the logic, but now I'm a little unsure how to handle the tests."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-12-14 07:53:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Could you first reply my basic questions?'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-12-14 16:45:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

-1 for clarification'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-12-15 18:08:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

It seem you didn't check the cover comment, so I copied my comments in the previous patch set."}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2018-12-18 21:35:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> FLOATING_IP_INCLUDE_TAGS:
> 
> If this setting is configured, floating IP pools which are not listed
> in this setting are not displayed. What is a use case where it is required?

The particular use case we're facing is the desire to present a simplified interface to users working with the GUI without preventing more advanced users from utilizing additional networks via the CLI or API.

This is about the *display* of networks, not *access control* of networks.

> FLOATING_IP_EXCLUDE_TTAGS:
> My comment is similar to for FLOATING_IP_INCLUDE_TAGS.
> I cannot imagine a use case where this is required and Neutron RBAC does not cover.

My answer is the same to FLOATING_IP_INCLUDE_TAGS :).  These settings are for controlling the display of items in the web UI, and do not have anything to do with access control.  Neutron RBAC would be inappropriate for this purpose."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-01-03 21:19:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I still don't understand the use-case of this. RFE in the Launchpad describes a bit different issue which is absolutely reasonable for me. If we just hide some Floating IP pool on the UI user will be able to use it via CLI or directly via API"}, {'account_id': 8745, 'date': '2019-03-11 19:12:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
allow operator to control display of floating ip pools

introduces FLOATING_IP_EXCLUDE_TAGS (do not show pool marked with the
listed tags), FLOATING_IP_INCLUDE_TAGS (only show pool marked with the
listed tags), and FLOATING_IP_ORDER_TAGS (control ordering of floating
ip pools in using tags).

Change-Id: I9a5cd61832e09b41a38442015d3dbb42cb6d8fd8
Closes-bug: #1807527

commit_message:
Add retry handling to MaaS OCF DNS API calls

This patchset adds retries to the MaaS API calls with the the
maas_dns.py script to allow Maas/PostGRES to 'settle' during failover
situations.  This should enable corosync to successfully update the DNS
records by allowing extra time for MaaS to settle and to detect when the
transient failures from the MaaS occur.

Closes-Bug: #1817429
Change-Id: I5180508ba236c60b7b677e226914e7fcd13c3020

commit_message:
restrict docker xfs ftype check to /var/lib/docker

The existing check for xfs filesystems with ftype=0 is too broad, and
will cause the deploy to fail even when docker has been configured
with an appropriate filesystem if / happens to have ftype=0.  This
change restricts the check to the filesystem containing
/var/lib/docker (or whichever path is configured in
container_registry_docker_fs).

Change-Id: Ice39d26f89a365ea3fdf95901b557c23810c6bfb

Yes, I noticed the cause. However, I am not sure about the simplest way to explicitly enable a service plugin in neutron-tempest-plugin. Any pointer to this would be much appreciated. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-02-20 01:27:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> > The new extension seems not loaded:

 > 
 > Yes, I noticed the cause. However, I am not sure about the simplest
 > way to explicitly enable a service plugin in neutron-tempest-plugin.
 > Any pointer to this would be much appreciated. Thanks!

This is one example for neutron server to enable the 'qos' service plugin:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/devstack/lib/qos#L2

And this is to enable 'qos' extension for l2 agent:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/devstack/lib/qos#L12

Yes, all there should be done in neutron repo. You can enable this service plugin in your neutron server side patch:

[{'created': '2019-02-24 18:24:41.000000000', 'message': 'Fix parallel plug vip

A recent patch[1] introduced parallel network configuration on load
balancer boot. However, this patch has a race condition between the
parallel booting amphora.
This patch corrects this by making the get amphora network configurations
task to work on a single amphora if one is presented to the task.

Change-Id: Ideb050a215b0b0335ea94163650959994f987008
Story: 2005080
Task: 29659

commit_message:
Fix parallel plug vip

A recent patch[1] introduced parallel network configuration on load
balancer boot. However, this patch has a race condition between the
parallel booting amphora.
This patch corrects this by making the get amphora network configurations
task to work on a single amphora if one is presented to the task.

Change-Id: Ideb050a215b0b0335ea94163650959994f987008
Story: 2005080
Task: 29659

commit_message:
Use setuptools instead of distribute (which is part of devel)

By building the package with setuptools, we ensure it is compatible
with pip 10 and above which require file manifests to be packaged.

Change-Id: I1a387deb91a3442ee4376105c6a1da8d0845b7a4

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-11 13:22:59.000000000', 'message': "Fix bootstrap-servers on Ansible 2.6+

Recently as part of adding support for Docker CE we added the following
task to the baremetal role:

- name: Update yum cache
  yum:
    update_cache: yes
  become: True
  when: ansible_os_family == 'RedHat'

This works fine on Ansible 2.5, but no longer works on Ansible
2.6, which complains that either the 'name' or 'list' argument
is mandatory for the yum module.

This change updates the cache later on, when installing packages.

Change-Id: I1a158bda52c4e362cb12d361d7f961cfc699b385
Closes-Bug: #1819173
(cherry picked from commit 1b5353593c8f17594b7d39015b6093ef2ae65b14)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix bootstrap-servers on Ansible 2.6+

Recently as part of adding support for Docker CE we added the following
task to the baremetal role:

- name: Update yum cache
  yum:
    update_cache: yes
  become: True
  when: ansible_os_family == 'RedHat'

This works fine on Ansible 2.5, but no longer works on Ansible
2.6, which complains that either the 'name' or 'list' argument
is mandatory for the yum module.

This change updates the cache later on, when installing packages.

Change-Id: I1a158bda52c4e362cb12d361d7f961cfc699b385
Closes-Bug: #1819173
(cherry picked from commit 1b5353593c8f17594b7d39015b6093ef2ae65b14)

commit_message:
Remove explict sed for doc build warnings

This is now obsolete, as the %py_req_cleanup macro does that
as a side-effect.

Change-Id: Ib3d19234f8e8abfb99bf4afd2140958eef9a0f87

commit_message:
Remove docutils requirement

This requirements was added [1] in order to run pep8 with a check
that has been subsequently removed [2].  It should have been a
test-requirement in the first place, and now tox runs just fine
without it.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/573474

[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614286/

Change-Id: I14015139ccd0cb509bb0d50c1e65af13ec11bd7c

[{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-08 00:27:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-08 00:28:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-03-08 03:33:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-03-08 13:55:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

LGTM - reflects the TC ad-hoc meeting last night'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-08 13:58:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Looks correct, and follows the process we set down.

As mentioned in IRC, I'd prefer projects to just use the 36/37 templates, rather than add indirection here. But this isn't the right time or place to argue that."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-08 14:11:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

> Looks correct, and follows the process we set down.
 > 
 > As mentioned in IRC, I'd prefer projects to just use the 36/37
 > templates, rather than add indirection here. But this isn't the
 > right time or place to argue that.

I feel template is much more easy to control the set of jobs we want projects to run. adding both jobs template separately make thinks complex in term or consistency to all projects and communication too. 

during zuul run we can till see actual job name running like openstack-tox-py36 and openstack-tox-py37"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-03-08 14:29:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-08 15:03:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

The templates look fine.

As someone who has just finished a major push to update job settings in all the repos, I think we'll make life easier for everyone if we can apply the templates centrally. That would mean adding and updating branch specifiers, but that could be done with 1 patch instead of a few hundred."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-03-11 06:03:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

AFAIK, we've never had templates with release names it in like this.  I think that is similar to the prior point about just using explicit -36/-37 job names.

I guess I don't see any reason not to, except it's a bit of "inside baseball" knowledge to realise what this expands to if you're looking at your zuul jobs.  OTOH, the abstraction is probably good for people who just want to look at the zuul jobs and say "great, we're $release compliant" :)  Goes both ways.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-11 13:43:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-11 13:43:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Incidentally, I responded to jroll's comments on IRC here:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2019-03-08.log.html#t2019-03-08T14:28:20"}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:00:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

The main thing which makes the per-cycle template cumbersome is that it will need to be added to (and eventually removed from) every single project to which it is applicable, whereas if we had a template which was reused cycle after cycle (openstack-pti-python or something) we'd only need to apply it to those projects once and then could merely update the template thereafter.

As an aside, what's the reason for leaving the Python 2.7 jobs out of these templates? What about docs builds or other jobs we require of all project covered by the Python PTI? It seems to me the convenience of this template would be that when a project is ready to start work on Train they can just add one per-language template and be assured that all the jobs required by the PTI will be run.

Anyway, while I'm not keen on the approach of adding and deleting templates from every project a couple times each year, I'm willing to consider the experiment and we can decide next cycle if any benefits outweigh the inconvenience."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:04:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, another question... can't we put the branch filters in the templates rather than having to duplicate them across every project?"}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:18:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Oh, another question... can't we put the branch filters in the templates rather than having to duplicate them across every project?

1) Yes
2) There are no branch filters required for this particular template"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:21:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

> The main thing which makes the per-cycle template cumbersome is
 > that it will need to be added to (and eventually removed from)
 > every single project to which it is applicable, whereas if we had a
 > template which was reused cycle after cycle (openstack-pti-python
 > or something) we'd only need to apply it to those projects once and
 > then could merely update the template thereafter.

This is why I suggested we apply the template to all projects in 1 place in 1 repo. I don't know if project-config is the right place for that, or if we want something that is more purely managed by the openstack project in our new opendev multi-tenant world. I thought using a separate template for each series would make it easier to see which jobs applied in a given series, rather than having a human have to figure out the branch specifiers if we use a single template. I'll defer to others on that point, but as someone who just had to submit a bunch of zuul patches to projects I do strongly suggest that we find a way to make the transition for each cycle *not* require touching every single repository.

 > As an aside, what's the reason for leaving the Python 2.7 jobs out
 > of these templates? What about docs builds or other jobs we require
 > of all project covered by the Python PTI? It seems to me the

The doc jobs are already singletons that are updated when those need to change, aren't they?

 > convenience of this template would be that when a project is ready
 > to start work on Train they can just add one per-language template
 > and be assured that all the jobs required by the PTI will be run.
 > 
 > Anyway, while I'm not keen on the approach of adding and deleting
 > templates from every project a couple times each year, I'm willing
 > to consider the experiment and we can decide next cycle if any
 > benefits outweigh the inconvenience."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-11 17:38:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Would it save time if I just listed all the places we discussed this already prior to ratifying this process in a TC resolution?

* https://review.openstack.org/572535
* http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135906.html
* http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/136140.html
* http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-10-30.log.html#t2018-10-30T16:49:37
* http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-11-02.log.html#t2018-11-02T19:02:21
* http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-11-30.log.html'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-03-11 17:56:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I'm not happy with the proposal since it involves changing all repos.

But if you all want to try it, let's do it... It might be the least evil ;)

Now with 4 +2s and all the TC+1s and the TC vote, let's merge  - and if a better solution comes along, we can revert/update..."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-08 00:27:34.000000000', 'message': 'Add Python3 project templates for Train release

Following the process set down in the TC resolution on updating Python
versions:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20181024-python-update-process.html

this change adds the Zuul template for Python 3 unit test jobs in the
Train release. The TC has determined that:

* The latest released version of Python that is available for testing is
  3.7.
* The only version of Python 3 that is the default in the
  distributions listed in the PTI (CentOS 7, Ubuntu 18.04 Bionic, openSUSE
  Leap 15) is Python 3.6. (Python 2.7 is the default in CentOS 7.)
* All Xenial-based integration tests will be migrated to Bionic before
  the Train cycle begins, so there is no need to test Python 3.5.

Therefore the Python 3 versions unit tested in Train will be Python 3.6
and Python 3.7. (Python 2.7 will also be tested.)

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc_python3/2019/tc_python3.2019-03-07-21.00.html

commit_message:
Add Python3 project templates for Train release

Following the process set down in the TC resolution on updating Python
versions:

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20181024-python-update-process.html

this change adds the Zuul template for Python 3 unit test jobs in the
Train release. The TC has determined that:

* The latest released version of Python that is available for testing is
  3.7.
* The only version of Python 3 that is the default in the
  distributions listed in the PTI (CentOS 7, Ubuntu 18.04 Bionic, openSUSE
  Leap 15) is Python 3.6. (Python 2.7 is the default in CentOS 7.)
* All Xenial-based integration tests will be migrated to Bionic before
  the Train cycle begins, so there is no need to test Python 3.5.

Therefore the Python 3 versions unit tested in Train will be Python 3.6
and Python 3.7. (Python 2.7 will also be tested.)

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tc_python3/2019/tc_python3.2019-03-07-21.00.html

Change-Id: I8b5fc61a6e1c192efed22bfd02155e22187464c1

[{'created': '2019-03-02 15:44:13.000000000', 'message': "Move pep8 requirements in to test-requirements

We had these in tox.ini before to streamline pep8 (it didn't need
to actually install openstacksdk) But now that we're doing local
hacking checks, we have to install the code, which means this
optimization is bong. Put things back in test-requirements like
sane people.

Note: this removes readme, which was there ostensibly to check
the readme file for validity - but we weren't actually using it.
It's not in global-requirements, so since we weren't using it
it seems like removing it is the better choice than getting it
added to g-r.

commit_message:
Move pep8 requirements in to test-requirements

We had these in tox.ini before to streamline pep8 (it didn't need
to actually install openstacksdk) But now that we're doing local
hacking checks, we have to install the code, which means this
optimization is bong. Put things back in test-requirements like
sane people. While doing that, remove readme, which isn't in
openstack/requirements and just let doc8 check it.

Change-Id: Id1860a1df33610ad7072c13ef9ee61395b785b94

commit_message:
Update Helm to version 2.13.0

This updates Helm from version v2.12.3 to v2.13.0.
The `merge` function has changed behavior, and is now called
`mergeOverwrite`.

commit_message:
Remove extraction warning from README

The warning in the readme is a bit old and confusing now
that placement is extracted and can be installed standalone
separate from nova in Stein and is its own project under
openstack TC governance, so this just removes the warning.

Change-Id: I69066cf21327677734c814fd7211135ff672ec3a
Story: #2005190
Task: 29946

This looks like it should be fine, but I'll leave it to Brian to confirm his concerns are addressed and approve it."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-03-05 14:42:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review Workflow-1

(1 comment)

@Jeremy: thanks for generating the output.

I'm putting a workflow hold on it until we've had a chance to discuss how we will handle this at Thursday's Glance weekly meeting.

Here is my concern with this change.  Glance has not implemented the "policies-in-code" community goal: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/policy-in-code.html#glance

Thus, operators need to be aware that our policy behavior is slightly different from the projects that *have* implemented the goal.  For those projects, sensible default values are defined in the code, so you can run them without a policy configuration file and pretty much expect normal behavior.

With glance, the only policies defined in code are the DEFAULT_RULES at line 35 in policy.py.  The reason Jeremy got a list with > 3 rules is because of line 46, where we load the policies out of the file if it exists; so what we're seeing in Jeremy's output is the current policy file converted to YAML (I'm not sure why the ordering is so weird, though).

The good news is that the current DEFAULT_RULES result in a secure configuration: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glance/commit/etc/policy.json?id=969309ffae15a56474e5a66100979a6bd76c356f -- only an admin will be able to do anything with Glance.

Cyril's result of generating an empty file is a bit strange, I'm not sure what's up with that, but an empty file would also be secure (it would match no targets and *no one* would be able to do anything with Glance).

If the above is correct, this seems OK so far.  The concern I have if an operator generates the file, likes what's in there, and then (as you can do with the other services) decides to deploy glance without a policy file; the operator will see completely different behavior than is expected.  We need to document this.  Or, we could override the policy generator to give a message explaining the situation.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-03-07 16:26:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Workflow

Conclusion from today's Glance meeting is that mentioning something about this in a releasenote should be sufficient."}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-03-11 05:58:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

hi Cyril,

Could you please add note in the glance docs as suggested by Brian?

Thank you!!!'}, {'account_id': 29759, 'date': '2019-03-11 07:47:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-03-11 12:43:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Will include the note discussed during the meeting into the release notes.

Thanks Cyril. If we want to go further than that, explaining how this works, we can add doc follow up patch.'}]

Add an oslo.policy.enforcer entrypoint

information about Glance policies.

Closes-Bug: #1816647

[{'created': '2019-03-04 13:56:12.000000000', 'message': 'Allocation API: optimize check on candidate nodes

Currently we fetch all nodes one by one when validating the provided
candidate_nodes. This is not overly efficient, so this change introduces
a new database API to specifically validate a list of names/uuids and
convert it to uuids. As a nice side effect, no database query is done
for identities that cannot be a valid node name or uuid.

Change-Id: I7adfe897200b1b05d9e632c68d0d3d046c06a921
Story: #2004341
'}]
commit_message:
Allocation API: optimize check on candidate nodes

Currently we fetch all nodes one by one when validating the provided
candidate_nodes. This is not overly efficient, so this change introduces
a new database API to specifically validate a list of names/uuids and
convert it to uuids. As a nice side effect, no database query is done
for identities that cannot be a valid node name or uuid.

Change-Id: I7adfe897200b1b05d9e632c68d0d3d046c06a921
Story: #2004341

(4 comments)

standalone fails as there is no libvirt-daemon package installed and we don't have /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf:

Feb 28 14:58:50 standalone.localdomain podman[28726]: 2019-02-28 14:58:50.240+0000: 28811: error : main:1054 : Can't load config file: Failed to open file '/etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf': No such file or directory: /etc/libvirt/virtlogd.conf

we just don't fail in host_prep at:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-puppet.yaml#L786


I think we need to understand why we have subdirs in qemu on rhel8 in var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt:

var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks/autostart

They need to be in /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/nova_libvirt/ on the host, where I don't see this in rhel7. Or we need to install libvirt-daemon on standalone host."}, {'account_id': 17216, 'date': '2019-03-01 16:13:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-03-08 11:05:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-27 10:14:03.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Unify /etc/libvirt mountpoints in nova_virtlogd and nova_libvirt

On a rhel8 os + rhel8 containers we seem to be getting the following
error from kolla in nova_virtlogd:

[stack@win1 ~]$ sudo podman logs nova_virtlogd
+sudo -E kolla_set_configs
OSError: [Errno 30] Read-only file system

The reason is the following
nova_virtlogd:
...
                  - /etc/libvirt/qemu:/etc/libvirt/qemu:ro

Seems kolla config has a some empty folders that are then copied to a :ro fs and we fail:
()[root@win1 /]$ find var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks/autostart

It seems the empty folders are copied in because
in https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/base/nova/libvirt.pp#L58-L63
we remove the default.xml and that likely changes the timestamps of
those folders and so they get copied in
/var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated and kolla will want to copy those
dirs but will fail due to the RO bind mount

Change-Id: I009c68b7821612684489b0ff407e286c5776d649

'}, {'created': '2019-03-10 20:11:43.000000000', 'message': 'Unify /etc/libvirt mountpoints in nova_virtlogd and nova_libvirt

On a rhel8 os + rhel8 containers we seem to be getting the following
error from kolla in nova_virtlogd:

[stack@win1 ~]$ sudo podman logs nova_virtlogd
+sudo -E kolla_set_configs
OSError: [Errno 30] Read-only file system

The reason is the following
nova_virtlogd:
...
                  - /etc/libvirt/qemu:/etc/libvirt/qemu:ro

Seems kolla config has a some empty folders that are then copied to a :ro fs and we fail:
()[root@win1 /]$ find var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks/autostart

It seems the empty folders are copied in because
in https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/base/nova/libvirt.pp#L58-L63
we remove the default.xml and that likely changes the timestamps of
those folders and so they get copied in
/var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated and kolla will want to copy those
dirs but will fail due to the RO bind mount

Change-Id: I009c68b7821612684489b0ff407e286c5776d649
'}]
commit_message:
Unify /etc/libvirt mountpoints in nova_virtlogd and nova_libvirt

On a rhel8 os + rhel8 containers we seem to be getting the following
error from kolla in nova_virtlogd:

[stack@win1 ~]$ sudo podman logs nova_virtlogd
+sudo -E kolla_set_configs
OSError: [Errno 30] Read-only file system

The reason is the following
nova_virtlogd:
...
                  - /etc/libvirt/qemu:/etc/libvirt/qemu:ro

Seems kolla config has a some empty folders that are then copied to a :ro fs and we fail:
()[root@win1 /]$ find var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks
var/lib/kolla/config_files/src/etc/libvirt/qemu/networks/autostart

It seems the empty folders are copied in because
in https://github.com/openstack/puppet-tripleo/blob/master/manifests/profile/base/nova/libvirt.pp#L58-L63
we remove the default.xml and that likely changes the timestamps of
those folders and so they get copied in
/var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated and kolla will want to copy those
dirs but will fail due to the RO bind mount

Change-Id: I009c68b7821612684489b0ff407e286c5776d649

commit_message:
Stop requiring root_gb for whole-disk images

This parameter makes no sense for them and is actually ignored after
validation. This change makes it optional (still allowed for backward
compatibility). Also cleanly separate validation code for partition and
whole-disk images.

Change-Id: I98da7d54cc6dd158d415e83c61659badc83fbeda
Story: #2005165
Task: #29895

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-01 22:57:54.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] -- Health probe for Nova components

Health probe for Nova pods is used for both liveness
and readiness probe.

nova-compute, nova-conductor, nova-consoleauth and nova-scheduler:
sends an RPC call with a non-existence method to component's queue.
Probe is success if agent returns with NoSuchMethod error.
If agent is not reachable or fails to respond in time,
returns failure to probe.

novnc/spice proxy: uses Kubernetes tcp probe on corresponding ports
they expose.

Change-Id: Ib8e4b93486588320fd2d562c3bc90b65844e52e5
"}, {'created': '2019-03-04 00:10:43.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] -- Health probe for Nova components

and readiness probe.

Change-Id: Ib8e4b93486588320fd2d562c3bc90b65844e52e5

Health probe for Nova pods is used for both liveness

nova-compute, nova-conductor, nova-consoleauth and nova-scheduler:
Check if the rpc socket status on the nova pods to rabbitmq and
database are in established state.
sends an RPC call with a non-existence method to component's queue.

returns failure to probe.

novnc/spice proxy: uses Kubernetes tcp probe on corresponding ports

Change-Id: Ib8e4b93486588320fd2d562c3bc90b65844e52e5

commit_message:
Health probe for Nova components

Health probe for Nova pods is used for both liveness
and readiness probe.

nova-compute, nova-conductor, nova-consoleauth and nova-scheduler:
Check if the rpc socket status on the nova pods to rabbitmq and
database are in established state.
sends an RPC call with a non-existence method to component's queue.
Probe is success if agent returns with NoSuchMethod error.
If agent is not reachable or fails to respond in time,
returns failure to probe.

novnc/spice proxy: uses Kubernetes tcp probe on corresponding ports
they expose.
Added code to catch nova config file not present exception.

Change-Id: Ib8e4b93486588320fd2d562c3bc90b65844e52e5

commit_message:
Make sure iptables-services gets pulled in on rhel8

Currently puppetlabs-firewall only pulls in the nftables package.
On rhel8 We want to pull in the iptables-services as puppet-firewall
needs the /usr/libexec/iptables/iptables[6].init scripts in order
to persist the iptables rules

Change-Id: If5fd9c7d4d1ded73291be93e8e04b24dfaa9c37d

in running unittests on box with no sudo and

that triggered this edge case

commit_message:
Skip tests based on service features disabled in tempest

It's not possible to know if services have certain features
enabled from the sevice API in certain cases. Let's leverage
the service specific feature groups in tempest. If a specific
service feature is disabled in tempest config, the decorated
tests would be skipped.

ex. If tempest.conf contains

[volume-feature-enabled]
backup = False

test_cinder_volume_create_backup_restore scenario test would be
skipped.

Change-Id: I7a2495182791595c87f8245ff5e13dfd841b013f

commit_message:
Clarify the Glance/metadefs relationship

I've answered a few questions recently for people who assumed that
since the metadefs service lives on the Glance endpoint, metadefs
have some kind of special relationship to images.  I think the
metadefs section of the api-ref makes it clear that this is not the
case (though it's not mentioned at all on the Images part of the
api-ref).  So here's an attempt to clarify issue (without being too
intrusive) right at the top of the Glance docs landing page.

Change-Id: I3dfbb09862acedb265a5a4557749bf52f6add5f4

subject: neutron Stein-3 beta deliverables
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 841, 'name': 'Akihiro Motoki', 'email': 'amotoki@gmail.com', 'username': 'amotoki'}, {'_account_id': 1131, 'name': 'Brian Haley', 'email': 'haleyb.dev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-haley'}, {'_account_id': 4694, 'name': 'Miguel Lavalle', 'email': 'miguel@mlavalle.com', 'username': 'minsel'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 11975, 'name': 'Slawek Kaplonski', 'email': 'skaplons@redhat.com', 'username': 'slaweq'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 29759, 'name': 'zhangmeng', 'email': 'zhangmeng9502@gmail.com', 'username': 'zhangmeng9502'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-03-07 14:48:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-03-07 14:50:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-03-07 16:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would like to wait for the fix ofl the neutron func test (which is near merge). -W until then.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-03-08 17:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Akihiro,

This is what we want to merge in Neutron:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/574783/ (Strict minimum bandwidth support (scheduling aware))

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/624708/, https://review.openstack.org/#/c/624709 (Network Segment Range Management)

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/640619/ (security weakness)

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/635311/ (RBAC for security groups)'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-03-08 18:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think we should also release neutron-lbaas, or I can update https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634717/ ?

Also, should these all have "b3" in their names as it is Stein-3 ?  Even if we didn't release one previously?'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-03-09 13:48:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Miguel, thanks for the info. I am also watching their status.

Brian, neutron-lbaas is under the octavia project, so the octavia team needs to release it. That's the reason I don't include neutron-lbaas in this patch."}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-10 08:46:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/624708/ merged'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-10 08:47:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/624709 merged'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-10 15:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/635311/ merged'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-10 21:15:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/640619/ merged'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-10 21:16:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/574783/ merged. So I think we are good to go now :)'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2019-03-10 22:14:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes! We are good to go. Everything merged'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-03-11 08:25:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-03-11 08:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Also, should these all have "b3" in their names as it is Stein-3 ?  Even if we didn't release one previously?

In Stein cycle, the release model was changed to release-with-rc and we no longer need to release deliverables per milestone. "bN" does not mean "milestone N". For example, neutron stein b1 was released between Stein-1 and Stein-2. It does not mean neutron Stein-1 deliverable.
Thus, I didn't change the version number in patch set 3.

On the other hand, I understand it makes it difficult to track which combinations of neutron stadium deliverables should work. We can continue to discuss what beta version should be used.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-03-11 08:43:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-11 10:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29759, 'date': '2019-03-11 13:22:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:28:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
neutron Stein-3 beta deliverables

Most stadium projects are tightly coupled with neutron from the same
release, so it is worth releasing all projects before RC.
Some projects already have beta releases, but some do not.

Change-Id: I17d8ee6ea3635ae6c4235e90a4398808b4a9e018
